content.description:
EDIT: Anchors have been added below the bulge making it 11c or so.

3 star climbing to a WTF finish. Start on two sick mono's and bust up the face with big moves on incut 2 and 3 finger pockets. Continue up the amazing clean line of pockets to a horizontal break which is unfortunately covered in bat poop. Rest up, fire a few steep moves, then grab your draw in frustration as the holds vanish. There is a fixed quick link on the last bolt which I happily lowered off. I honestly have no idea how to get to the chains, perhaps a hold broke? Or the more likely scenario is that I'm a weenie.
content.location: The right most side of the heavy metal sector. When the main trail hits the cliff, follow the trail right past the "easy listening slab" and a section with no routes. You will come to a clean white sector with 3 bolted routes, this is the right most one.

content.description: Short and bouldery.  Starts on jugs in lighter-colored rock before pulling through the bulge on pockets.
content.location: A small platform just right of the old Catalyst contains the first possible routes on the left side of the HMRB. It is 50’ right of where the cliff terminates into dirt and 50’ off the ground on a dirt ledge.  Hike past the main trail to base of the HMRB, another 50’, then look right for a faint game trail.  This is the short, left-most climb.

climbs.name: War Pigs
climbs.fa: 2018: C. Sanchez, S. Vedder, & the Morse-Bradys

content.description: Good pockets off the ground, to a dihedral crack, followed by jugs and two-finger pockets to the top.  A great warm-up for the area.
content.location: This climb starts atop a large block at the base of a left-facing dihedral crack.  Located approximately 20 feet to the left of the Goodnight Gorilla start.

content.description: Random route up a gulley and off a ledge.  Stick clip 1st bolt.  Jugs initially to a very awkward and technical transfer crux to face holds.  Good rock.  Brief crux, but, hard!
content.location: Up the gulley to the right of D&J's wall.  Really cool hang and on it's own.  Potential for 2 more routes at least.

content.description: One move slab problem leads to 30 feet of easy 5.8 pocket pulling above.  I found the opening move to be the the hardest move on the entire Easy Listening Wall.
content.location: This area is casually referred to as the Easy Listening Wall it is however right in the middle of HMRB and does not need its own area in this data base.  The Easy Listing Wall starts 40 right of Goodnight Moon just past the horizontal roof easily identified because it is a low angle pocket slab.  T-FPS is the 3rd route from the left.  Of the 2 short routes it is the right one.

content.description: Fun slab climbing up good pockets! The only bummer is the route can be quite dirty, but the holds are big enough that it shouldn't be an issue. One of the longest routes in the area.
content.protection: 11 Bolts, there is a mid way anchor as well but a 60M rope gets you down
content.location: On the heavy metal section, this is the right most slab route on the "Easy listening wall". Out of the 4 routes this is the right most one.

content.description: Face to prow up high.  Pockets and technical rock.
content.location: First route to the right of D&J's Adventure.  Lots of bolts.

content.description: Awesome climb! Pick your way up a fantastic series of moves on the clean white wall. After 5 bolts of amazing pockets you reach a small roof with good holds on the right side. Climb a few more bolts on slightly crumbly rock to the chains. It would be classic if the rock was better up top.
content.location: The right most side of the heavy metal sector. When the main trail hits the cliff, follow the trail right past the "easy listening slab" and a section with no routes. You will come to a clean white sector with 3 bolted routes, this is the left most one.

content.description: A short pocketed slab.  Thinner movers off the deck lead to bigger slightly muddy pockets above.  Make no mistake this route is well cleaned and doesn't feel dirty per say, but likely spring run off leads to a little mud deep in the big pockets.
content.location: This area is casually referred to as the Easy Listening Wall it is however right in the middle of HMRB and does not need its own area in this data base.  The Easy Listing Wall starts 40 right of Goodnight Moon just past the horizontal roof easily identified because it is a low angle pocket slab.  Smooth Jazz is the second route from the left and is the left of the 2 short routes in the middle of the wall.

content.description: This is a steep line that follows a clean face to bulge at the top.  Clip a bolt from the ground and head through some steep pockets to better rock above. Expect thuggish pocket tossing, delicate traverses, and a devious bulge.  North-facing, this climb sees one hour of late morning sun and is steep enough to climb in the rain.
content.location: I’m loosely calling this little area the Crow's Nest, as it sits above the main cliff.  The best way to describe it is that it contains the first possible routes on the left side of the HMRB. It is 50’ right of where the cliff terminates into dirt and 50’ off the ground on a dirt ledge.  Hike past the main trail to base of the HMRB, another 50’, then look right for a faint short game trail ending at the white, north-facing overhang.

content.description:
The Skunk Ape is an under-appreciated species of the Dinanthropoides genus.  As children, we would hear the Skunk Apes frolicking in the thick New England timber, breeding fear, anticipation, and excitement in all those who heard their calls.  Confirmed sightings were rare...but never disputed.

Like the flesh-and-bones Skunk Ape, the climb is a bona fide 5.9+.  Not some washed out overrated Bigfoot horseshit.

Please be mindful of the belay, as it is delicate soil and will not last if humans trounce it like a cheap throw rug.
content.protection: Snapdragons, half a baker's dozen should cover you.
content.location: Find Heavy Metal -- check.  Identify one of the the obvious hard lines near the roof (Goodnight Gorilla and Darkness are easy to identify) -- check.  Count over to the left from there.  MP is complete and well-documented in this zone.

content.description:
Likely the longest route in the Heavy Metal, please tie a knot in the end of your rope.  Heads up on one of the prettiest streaked headwalls in the canyon.

Rat's Eyes has a variety of climbing styles, including laybacking, pocket pulling, jug hauling, and small hold technical climbing.
content.protection: 12 glue-in bolts to clip-and-lower anchors.  *Be sure to have a full 60 meter rope.*
content.location:
On the rightmost side of the Spinal Tap area.  Hike up past the giant flake buried in the earth below

The Amp that Goes to 11

and

When the Levee Breaks

, just past said buried flake look for a fat glue in bolt and layback feature that leads to thin glue in bolts that go out of eyesight.  Furthest right route on this panel of rock, look for the beautiful streaked upper headwall when you stand back.

content.description: Hardest part (and nicest) is the face up high.  Mostly pretty mellow pockets.
content.location: This route is to the right of Surround Sound, just past the tunnel.

content.description: Small prow of sorts.  Pockets and jugs.  Black and grey rock.  Fun.
content.location: Hidden and on it's own.  Just past D&J's Adventure and above trail.  Before you get to the wall with Indian Summer.

content.description: Start in a left-trending crack, before pulling onto the face.  Big pockets lead to mono(s), then long reaches between pockets to the finish.
content.location: As you come down the trail to a flat belay station with a cave, you will see a low-angle ramp.  This climb is just right of the left-facing crack/dihedral, and starts at the bottom of this feature.

content.description: Good stemming leads to a rolling low angle pocketed face.  Excellent for the grade.
content.location: This area is casually referred to as the Easy Listening Wall it is however right in the middle of HMRB and does not need its own area in this data base.  The Easy Listing Wall starts 40 right of Goodnight Moon just past the horizontal roof easily identified because it is a low angle pocket slab.  Kenny G's Amphitheater is leftmost route on this wall starts with a stem corner which is on.

content.description: Follow a ramp up and right to an easy first clip, then straight up over a very small no-pull roof. Large pockets up mostly vertical face, with a fun final pull to the anchor. Worthwhile despite loose rock; the holds are all there.
content.location: The rightmost route on the wall, just right of George's Last Stand.

content.description: Start on a techy lower section, followed by a sequency crux.  Pull through a small bulge to a juggy headwall.
content.location:
This climb starts on top of a small leaning flake at the base of the cliff, and skirts to the left side of a small roof feature at about 30 feet up.  Just left of

Spinal Tap.

content.description: Absolutely incredible. A must do at the shady side. Start up a layback flake to clip the first bolt, then traverse out left on incut pockets to the second bolt. Launch into the crux using a single pad mono to a higher sinker mono. Clip the third bolt and follow good pockets with small feet to the chains. There are multiple ways to do the crux.
content.location: When you come up the gully, take a right when you reach the rock to access the Heavy Metal Cliff Band. Walk right along the cliff until you see a clean white face with a roof (goodnight gorilla 12b). Walk a little further and you will see a line of pockets that belongs at wild iris.

content.description: Great movement and stone quality. Underling crack to boulder problem followed by less-than-vert 5.11 climbing to the chains.
content.location: One of the first routes encountered after traversing right from Catalyst trail.  Defined by the undercling into roof section about 8 feet up leading into a impeccably clean but short head-wall.

content.description: Chosstateering at it's finest!  Literately the best chossy route I have ever done while not being able to give it more than one star.  The coveted sought after classic of the one star route connaisseur.  5.10 difficulty but 5.11 for over gripping and solid hold finding.  Fun big hold/crack movement around questionable rock.
content.protection: Grey painted hangers. 12 draws should cover your needs
content.location: This climb is the center piece of the "First Buttress" of the HMRB.  It goes up a crack right in the middle trending left at the top.  As of 2018 it is the only climb on the "First Buttress".  Look for grey painted hangers.

content.description: Juggy golden choss flakes intermixed with a thin hold or two.  Well-bolted but can feel runout due to the nature of the rock.  Not my favorite climb at the wall, but it is certainly worth trying once.
content.location: So you’ve reached the Heavy Metal Band... hike all the way right until the the cliff band ends at a rock outcropping (it sort of cliffs out at that point).  Look for a giant flake (or maybe it’s just a low angle ramp up the wall with bolts above) and you're there.  As of 2018 it was the 2nd to last bolt line.

content.description:
**

Named in honor of the ever-resilient dumpster kitties, who tragically lost their home in the dumpster fire of 2017.

**

Buckets to monos to buckets, oh my!  This short little number is slightly more devious than it looks.  Meow meow -- Kitty likes!
content.location: Begin atop a large boulder at the left end of the Heavy Metal area.  This is the second climb to the left of the obvious dihedral.

content.description: Bouldery opening sequence leads to big movement.  At half height the climb pulls onto a steepening headwall with good pockets.
content.location: From the old Catalyst trail (the one that takes you to the cliff band) traverse right along the cliff band for 5-10 minutes to the cluster of climbs which include Spinal Tap.  Its the first route on the left in this cluster.  The climb starts on dark rock leads to white head wall.

content.description: An interesting series of moves running the gamut from crimps to buckets and a knee bar if you're creative.  It ain't over till it's over!
content.location: 50 feet to the right of Spinal Tap, right around the corner.  This is the left of two routes which share the same start and the same finish.

content.description: Hard roof boulder problem at the start big holds/big movement stick clipping is advisable.  More deep pockets and big lock-offs characterize the rest of the route.  Enjoyable movement on quality clean stone.
content.location: So you’ve found the Heavy Metal Wall.  The first cluster of of routes on gorgeous stone are referred to as the Goodnight climbs.  Darkness on a Leash is immediately right of Night Goat, and is the centerpiece and only route that tackles the low roof. Look for a thick glue-in at the lip.

content.description: This route begins on a bucketed slab, with big moves between pockets.  After you reach a break, you transition onto a bulletproof headwall.  Hang on for good technical  climbing to the chains.
content.protection: 12 bolts to clip-and-lowers. *Be sure to have a full 60 meter rope.*
content.location:
This is the left "black streak" of the two streaks at the far right end of the wall that features

Spinal Tap

and other climbs.  Start atop a large detached flake, and continue up to the top of the wall.

content.description: Thoughtful climbing with good jugs at the top.
content.location: The second climb from the left in the cluster of climbs that includes Spinal Tap.  This climb starts up dark rock several feet to the right of a pine tree.

content.description: Excellent! Start with a boulder problem into 2 small monos by the second bolt. Then make a couple of big, really fun crosses to a jug at the bulge. Get a shake and climb the head wall up through big lock offs to incut pockets. Slightly harder, but just as good as Goodnight Gorilla. Another must-do at the shady side.
content.location: Just to the right of the "Goodnight Gorilla" roof

content.description: The Amp that Goes to 11 - Good pockets with fun moment and monos, leading to steeper but crumbly rock above.
content.location: Right of Spinal Tap, Left of When the Levee Breaks. Lacking a real defining feature its sort of in a "dip" between 2 routes that have bulges at the top.

content.description:
Start up face left of the flake.  At first bolt move right and vigorously lieback/face climb (7 or 8) the flake. Pockets and edges lead up and right above the flake, traversing right into a bowl.  The face above is pretty intimidating looking from the bowl, but has excellent edges and pockets.

Crux is moving past the 11th bolt.  Really nice climbing all the way, esp the upper face.
content.protection: 12 bolts protection.  Mussey hooks at anchor.
content.location: This climb starts right of Surround Sound, just left of the cave.
